questions.text: What is the preferred treatment of penicillin-resistant Gram-negative diplococci (Neisseria meningitidis)? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ceftriaxone

 

Ceftriaxone is the preferred treatment for penicillin-resistant Neisseria meningitidis. For penicillin-sensitive strains, intravenous penicillin G remains the treatment of choice. 

 

However, when dealing with penicillin-resistant strains or when empirical therapy for meningitis is needed, third-generation cephalosporins, particularly ceftriaxone, are considered the gold standard. 

 

Ceftriaxone has excellent penetration into the cerebrospinal fluid and provides reliable coverage against both penicillin-sensitive and penicillin-resistant Neisseria meningitidis strains. It is also the preferred empirical therapy for bacterial meningitis in most clinical scenarios.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tetracycline: This antibiotic does not have reliable activity against Neisseria meningitidis and is not recommended for treating meningococcal infections. It also has poor penetration into the central nervous system.

 

Option C. Amoxicillin: Like other penicillins, amoxicillin would be ineffective against penicillin-resistant strains of Neisseria meningitidis. It would only be appropriate for penicillin-sensitive strains, but even then, intravenous penicillin G would be preferred.

 

Option D. Vancomycin: This antibiotic is predominantly active against Gram-positive organisms and has no significant activity against Gram-negative bacteria like Neisseria meningitidis. It would be completely ineffective for treating meningococcal infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ceftriaxone is the preferred treatment for penicillin-resistant Neisseria meningitidis and the gold standard for empirical bacterial meningitis therapy.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a stimulus for catecholamine synthesis? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hyperglycemia

 

Hyperglycemia is not a stimulus for catecholamine synthesis. Physiologically, hyperglycemia can suppress catecholamine synthesis. While hyperglycemic emergencies may indirectly lead to increased catecholamines due to shock and osmotic diuresis, hyperglycemia itself does not directly stimulate catecholamine production. Hypoglycemia (not hyperglycemia) is a potent stimulus for catecholamine release, leading to autonomic symptoms like tremors, palpitations, anxiety, and sweating.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Smoking: Incorrect. Smoking is a known stimulus for catecholamine synthesis. Nicotine triggers the release of catecholamines from the adrenal medulla and sympathetic nerve endings.

 

Option B. Standing posture: Incorrect. Orthostatic changes require a catecholamine surge to prevent orthostatic hypotension when a person stands up. This is a normal physiological response.

 

Option D. Exercise: Incorrect. Exercise is one of the major physiological stimuli for catecholamine synthesis. Physical activity requires increased sympathetic activation and catecholamine production.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypoglycemia (not hyperglycemia) is a potent stimulus for catecholamine release, leading to autonomic symptoms like tremors, palpitations, anxiety, and sweating. Hyperglycemia does not stimulate catecholamine synthesis.

questions.text: Which of the following medications is most commonly associated with cholestasis in the absence of significant portal inflammation? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Estrogens/Androgen

 

Estrogens and androgens are known to cause bland cholestasis, which is characterized by cholestasis without portal inflammation. This type of drug-induced liver injury presents with elevated alkaline phosphatase and bilirubin but lacks the inflammatory component seen in other forms of drug-induced hepatotoxicity. 

 

Other drugs that can cause bland cholestasis include certain SERMs (especially tamoxifen), cyclosporine, griseofulvin, and some sulfonylureas. The mechanism involves direct interference with bile flow without causing significant hepatocellular damage or inflammatory infiltrate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acetaminophen: This drug causes centrilobular necrosis, which is a form of hepatocellular injury rather than cholestasis. It produces direct hepatotoxicity through metabolite-induced cellular damage, not cholestatic injury.

 

Option B. Amoxicillin-clavulanate: This combination is known to cause cholestatic hepatitis, which includes both cholestasis AND portal inflammation. It is currently considered one of the most common causes of drug-induced cholestasis worldwide, particularly in Caucasian populations, but it causes inflammatory cholestasis rather than bland cholestasis.

 

Option C. Isoniazid: This anti-tuberculosis drug typically causes hepatocellular injury rather than cholestasis. It can cause acute hepatitis with elevated transaminases but is not known for causing pure cholestatic injury without inflammation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Estrogens and androgens cause bland cholestasis (cholestasis without portal inflammation), while other drugs typically cause either hepatocellular injury or cholestatic hepatitis.

questions.text: Match the following hormones to receptors: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1-B, 2-A, 3-D, 4-C

 

  • (1-B) Acetylcholine works through ligand-gated channels (like other neurotransmitters such as serotonin and GABA)
  • (2-A) Insulin functions via the receptor tyrosine kinase (RTK) pathway, with insulin receptor substrate (IRS) as its substrate
  • (3-D) Growth hormone operates through the JAK-STAT pathway (non-receptor tyrosine kinase pathway)
  • (4-C) Thyroxine, being lipid-soluble, acts through nuclear receptors

 

Educational Objective:

 

The distinct receptor mechanisms for different hormone classes:

 

  • Acetylcholine → Ligand-gated channels
  • Insulin → Tyrosine kinase pathway
  • Growth hormone → JAK-STAT pathway
  • Thyroxine → Nuclear receptors

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of NAME syndrome? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ebstein's anomaly

 

NAME syndrome is now recognized as part of the Carney complex, which falls under Multiple Endocrine Other Organ Neoplasia (MEON). The NAME acronym stands for:

 

  • N: Nevi (blue nevi – skin manifestation)
  • A: Atrial myxoma
  • M: Myxoid neurofibroma
  • E: Ephelides (freckles)

 

Ebstein's anomaly is not a component of this syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:


NAME syndrome (now part of Carney complex) consists of Nevi (blue), Atrial myxoma, Myxoid neurofibroma, and Ephelides (freckles). Ebstein's anomaly is not a component of this syndrome.

choices.text: Making a fist with forearm exercise
Tourniquet should be tied and released as soon as possible
Should be collected in sitting position & better to avoid prolonged immobilization
Sample should be analyzed within 15–30 min of collection

questions.text: Which of the following should be prevented when collecting a blood sample for serum calcium? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Making a fist with forearm exercise

 

Making a fist and performing forearm exercises during blood collection for calcium measurement should be prevented, as it can cause muscle ischemia and erroneously increase the calcium value in the sample. This is a practical consideration during blood collection when lab personnel often ask patients to make a fist and perform repetitive movements to better visualize veins.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tourniquet should be tied and released as soon as possible: The tourniquet should be tied and released as soon as possible to avoid erroneously high calcium values. In some cases, for repeat calcium or PTH measurements, it's recommended to avoid tourniquet use altogether.

 

Option C. Should be collected in sitting position & better to avoid prolonged immobilization: Collecting samples in sitting position and avoiding prolonged immobilization is recommended, as standing can increase serum calcium levels. Prolonged sitting/immobilization can also affect values due to bone lysis.

 

Option D. Sample should be analyzed within 15–30 min of collection: Samples should ideally be analyzed within 15–30 minutes of collection. If delay is anticipated, the sample should be kept on ice (good for 2 hours) or centrifuged to obtain plasma/serum (stable at room temperature for 8 hours).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Making a fist and performing forearm exercises during blood collection for calcium measurement should be avoided, as it can falsely elevate calcium levels through muscle ischemia.

questions.text: In CN III palsy, which of the following is not affected? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Abduction

 

Cranial Nerve III (CN III), also known as the oculomotor nerve, innervates several muscles responsible for eye movements and eyelid elevation. These muscles include the superior rectus (elevation), medial rectus (adduction), inferior rectus (depression), and inferior oblique (extorsion and elevation in adduction). It also innervates the levator palpebrae superioris muscle, which is responsible for elevating the eyelid.

 

Abduction is controlled by the lateral rectus muscle, which is innervated by the abducens nerve (CN VI), not the oculomotor nerve. Therefore, abduction is not affected in CN III palsy.

 

Other Options:

 

In CN III palsy, the functions of these muscles are compromised, leading to issues such as:

 

Option A. Elevation: Elevation is affected due to the involvement of the superior rectus muscle innervated by CN III.

 

Option B. Adduction: Adduction is affected due to the involvement of the medial rectus muscle innervated by CN III.

 

Option D. Ptosis: Ptosis occurs due to the involvement of the levator palpebrae superioris muscle innervated by CN III.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In CN III palsy, abduction is not affected because it is controlled by the lateral rectus muscle, which is innervated by the abducens nerve (CN VI).

questions.text: Cannabinoids are approved in all of the following except: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Rett Syndrome

 

Rett Syndrome: A rare genetic neurological disorder that primarily affects girls and leads to severe cognitive and physical impairments. While new treatments are being explored, cannabinoids are not currently approved for managing this condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Cannabinoids, specifically cannabidiol (CBD) formulations such as Epidiolex, have been FDA-approved for use in treating certain epileptic syndromes. These include:

 

Option A. Dravet Syndrome: A severe form of epilepsy that begins in infancy, characterized by prolonged seizures.

 

Option B. Lennox-Gastaut Syndrome: A childhood-onset epilepsy that involves multiple types of seizures and often results in cognitive impairment.

 

Option C. Tuberous Sclerosis: A genetic disorder that causes benign tumors to form in many parts of the body, including the brain, which can lead to seizures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cannabinoids, such as Epidiolex, are approved for the treatment of Dravet Syndrome, Lennox-Gastaut Syndrome, and Tuberous Sclerosis, but not for Rett Syndrome.

 

Note - High-dose Epidiolex is an FDA-approved oil formulation of CBD for use as an add-on treatment for Dravet's and Lennox-Gastaut syndromes and tuberous sclerosis epilepsies. There is clinical evidence for CBD, at lower doses, as an anxiolytic for the treatment of posttraumatic stress, anxiety, and relapse of substance use disorders. Animal studies suggest that this effect of CBD may be mediated by the 5-hydroxytryptamine 1A receptor.

questions.text: Which of the following in IgA vasculitis warrants the use of corticosteroids? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) GI bleeding

 

IgA vasculitis, also known as Henoch-Schönlein purpura, typically presents with symptoms such as arthritis, abdominal pain, and skin rash. These symptoms are often managed with supportive care and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs). However, the use of corticosteroids is reserved for more severe manifestations of the disease.

 

GI bleeding: In cases where IgA vasculitis leads to gastrointestinal bleeding, corticosteroids are warranted. This is because GI bleeding indicates a severe form of the disease involving the gastrointestinal tract, which requires more aggressive treatment to reduce inflammation and prevent further complications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Arthritis: Joint pain and swelling associated with IgA vasculitis are usually mild and managed with NSAIDs or supportive care. Corticosteroids are not typically indicated for arthritis alone in this context.

 

Option C. Abdominal pain: Abdominal pain in IgA vasculitis can often be managed with supportive care and NSAIDs. Corticosteroids are reserved for severe cases or when there is evidence of significant gastrointestinal involvement.

 

Option D. Skin rash: The characteristic purpuric rash of IgA vasculitis is usually self-limiting and does not require corticosteroids for treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Corticosteroids are indicated in IgA vasculitis primarily for severe manifestations such as gastrointestinal bleeding, indicating more extensive disease involvement. Other manifestations, such as arthritis, abdominal pain, and skin rash, are generally self-limiting and respond well to supportive care. Corticosteroids are not typically required for these symptoms unless they are part of a more severe systemic involvement.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Dubin-Johnson Syndrome is incorrect? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Raised Alkaline Phosphatase

 

Explanation:

 

Dubin-Johnson syndrome is characterized by conjugated hyperbilirubinemia but normal alkaline phosphatase levels. This benign, rare disorder features defective expression of MRP2 (multidrug resistance-associated protein 2), an ATP-dependent canalicular membrane transporter responsible for biliary excretion of bilirubin conjugates. Despite the conjugated hyperbilirubinemia, liver tests other than bilirubin are typically normal in Dubin-Johnson syndrome, including alkaline phosphatase, which distinguishes it from other causes of conjugated hyperbilirubinemia like obstruction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Conjugated Hyperbilirubinemia: Dubin-Johnson syndrome presents with predominantly conjugated hyperbilirubinemia, with total bilirubin concentrations typically between 34-85 μmol/L (2-5 mg/dL).

 

Option C. Dark or Black liver on histology: A cardinal feature of Dubin-Johnson syndrome is the accumulation of dark, coarsely granular pigment in the lysosomes of centrilobular hepatocytes, resulting in a grossly black appearance of the liver.

 

Option D. Mutation of MRP2 Gene: Several different mutations in the MRP2 gene produce the Dubin-Johnson phenotype. MRP2 is undoubtedly important in the biliary excretion of conjugated bilirubin, and its defective expression is the molecular basis of this syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dubin-Johnson syndrome is distinguished from other causes of conjugated hyperbilirubinemia by normal liver biochemical tests (including normal alkaline phosphatase), and characteristic black pigmentation of the liver resulting from MRP2 deficiency.

questions.text: Which of the following is classified as a 'Small Vessel Vasculitis'? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Microscopic Polyangiitis

 

Microscopic polyangiitis is classified as a small vessel vasculitis in the Chapel classification of vasculitis (2012). It primarily affects capillaries, venules, and arterioles, which are the defining vessels involved in small vessel vasculitis. MPA is characterized by pauci-immune necrotizing vasculitis that frequently manifests with glomerulonephritis and pulmonary capillaritis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Polyarteritis Nodosa (PAN): PAN is classified as a medium vessel vasculitis. It predominantly affects medium and small muscular arteries, particularly at vessel bifurcations. Unlike small vessel vasculitides, PAN does not typically involve arterioles, capillaries, or venules.

 

Option C. Giant Cell Vasculitis: This is a large vessel vasculitis that primarily affects the aorta and its major branches, particularly the extracranial branches of the carotid artery. Its predilection for temporal arteries has given it the alternative name of temporal arteritis.

 

Option D. Takayasu's Disease: Takayasu arteritis is classified as a large vessel vasculitis. It primarily affects the aorta and its branches, with a strong predilection for the aortic arch and its major branches. Subclavian artery involvement is most common (93% of cases).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Microscopic polyangiitis is a small vessel vasculitis characterized by necrotizing vasculitis affecting small vessels with few or no immune complexes. It commonly presents with glomerulonephritis and pulmonary capillaritis, and is frequently associated with p-ANCA (anti-MPO) antibodies, distinguishing it from other vessel-specific vasculitides.

questions.text: C-ANCA positivity is highly specific for?(NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Wegener's granulomatosis

 

Explanation:

 

C-ANCA (cytoplasmic antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies) with specificity for proteinase-3 is highly specific for Wegener's granulomatosis, now called granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA). More than 90% of patients with typical active granulomatosis with polyangiitis have detectable antibodies to proteinase-3. The specificity of antiproteinase-3 antibodies for Wegener's granulomatosis is very high (>95%), making it a valuable diagnostic marker.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Polyarteritis nodosa: Polyarteritis nodosa is ANCA-negative. It is a non-granulomatous medium vessel vasculitis without glomerulonephritis or pulmonary involvement, often featuring testicular involvement and microaneurysms visible on angiography.

 

Option C. Henoch-Schonlein purpura: HSP (now called IgA vasculitis) is characterized by IgA-mediated vasculitis with immune complex deposition rather than ANCA association. Diagnosis involves skin biopsy with direct immunofluorescence showing leukocytoclastic vasculitis with IgA and C3 deposition in vessel walls.

 

Option D. Churg-Strauss syndrome: Now called eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (EGPA), this condition is primarily associated with p-ANCA (perinuclear ANCA) with antimyeloperoxidase specificity rather than c-ANCA. Approximately 48% of patients with EGPA have circulating ANCA that is usually antimyeloperoxidase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

C-ANCA with anti-proteinase-3 specificity serves as a highly specific serological marker for granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener's), providing an important diagnostic tool that helps differentiate it from other vasculitides that are either ANCA-negative or associated with different ANCA patterns.

questions.text: Pseudo P pulmonale is seen in which electrolyte abnormality? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Hypokalemia

 

Pseudo P pulmonale, characterized by exaggerated amplitude in the P wave, can be observed on an ECG in the context of hypokalemia. This electrolyte disturbance affects cardiac electrophysiology, leading to various changes including prolonged QT interval, presence of U waves, T wave flattening or inversion, and sometimes pseudo-infarction patterns, which can mimic myocardial infarction.

 

Hypokalemia can result in these distinct ECG changes due to its influence on cellular membrane potentials in cardiac cells, which alters the normal propagation of electrical impulses through the myocardium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hyponatremia: Does not typically cause prominent P wave changes; its ECG manifestations are less specific and often involve general effects on conduction and contractility.

 

Note - Hyponatremia is usually silent on the ECG

 

Option C. Hypocalcemia: Associated with prolonged QT interval due to an elongation of the ST segment but not with pseudo P pulmonale.

 

Option D. Hypercalcemia: Typically presents with a shortened QT interval and shortened ST segment, differing significantly from the changes seen in hypokalemia.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Prophylaxis is available for all of the following, except: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Hepatitis C

 

Explanation:

 

No effective prophylaxis is currently available for hepatitis C. Unlike hepatitis A, B, and E, there is no vaccine or immunoglobulin preparation that can provide passive or active immunization against HCV infection. The primary preventive strategies for hepatitis C focus on screening blood products, avoiding needle sharing, and implementing universal precautions in healthcare settings. Post-exposure prophylaxis with antiviral agents has not been established as effective for preventing HCV infection after exposure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hepatitis A: Prophylaxis for hepatitis A is available through both active and passive immunization. Active immunization involves formalin-inactivated vaccines (Havrix and Vaqta), while passive immunization uses immune globulin (IG). Hepatitis A vaccination provides long-lasting protection, and IG can be effective when administered before exposure or early in the incubation period.

 

Option B. Hepatitis B: Both active and passive prophylaxis are available for hepatitis B. Active immunization uses recombinant vaccines containing HBsAg (Recombivax-HB and Engerix-B). Passive immunization with hepatitis B immunoglobulin (HBIG) is used for post-exposure prophylaxis. The combination of HBIG and vaccine is recommended for certain high-risk exposures.

 

Option D. Hepatitis E: Safe and effective recombinant vaccines for hepatitis E have been developed and are available in endemic areas. The Chinese hepatitis E vaccine has demonstrated long-lasting protection in clinical trials, documented for up to 4.5 years. While not widely available in the United States, prophylaxis for hepatitis E does exist.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hepatitis C stands alone among the major hepatitis viruses as having no established prophylactic vaccine or immunoglobulin preparation, making prevention dependent on avoiding exposure.

questions.text: Which of the following is not typically associated with Type I Cryoglobulinemia? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Strongly Positive Rheumatoid factor

 

Type I cryoglobulinemia is characterized by the presence of monoclonal immunoglobulins (usually IgM or IgG) that precipitate in cold temperatures. Type I cryoglobulinemia features include monoclonal Ig (usually IgM), hyperviscosity, thrombosis, and normal complement levels. Unlike Types II and III (mixed cryoglobulinemias), Type I cryoglobulinemia is not associated with rheumatoid factor activity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hyperviscosity: This is incorrect as an answer because hyperviscosity is a key feature of Type I cryoglobulinemia. The monoclonal paraproteins in Type I can lead to symptoms of hyperviscosity, including visual disturbances, headaches, and neurological symptoms.

 

Option B. Monoclonal IgM paraprotein: This is incorrect as an answer because monoclonal immunoglobulins, particularly IgM, are the defining characteristic of Type I cryoglobulinemia, typically associated with plasma cell dyscrasias.

 

Option C. Normal complement levels: This is incorrect as an answer because Type I cryoglobulinemia is indeed associated with normal C3/C4 complement levels, unlike the hypocomplementemia seen in Type II mixed cryoglobulinemia.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Type I cryoglobulinemia is characterized by monoclonal immunoglobulins, hyperviscosity, and normal complement levels, but lacks the rheumatoid factor activity that is characteristic of mixed cryoglobulinemias (Types II and III).

questions.text: Primary adrenal insufficiency causes all of the following, except? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Increased protein breakdown

 

Explanation:

 

Primary adrenal insufficiency (Addison's disease) involves impaired production of glucocorticoids, mineralocorticoids, and adrenal androgen precursors. While glucocorticoid deficiency can affect protein metabolism, it actually leads to decreased protein breakdown (catabolism), not increased. Glucocorticoids normally promote protein catabolism, so in their absence, protein breakdown is reduced rather than increased.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Low blood pressure: This is a classic feature of primary adrenal insufficiency. Mineralocorticoid deficiency causes sodium wasting and volume depletion, resulting in hypotension and often postural hypotension, which can be profound in adrenal crisis.

 

Option B. Decrease in extracellular fluid (ECF): This is correct for primary adrenal insufficiency. Aldosterone deficiency leads to sodium loss and water excretion, reducing ECF volume. This contributes to the hypotension seen in Addison's disease and is part of the clinical presentation.

 

Option C. Decreased sodium to potassium ratio: This is accurate for primary adrenal insufficiency. Mineralocorticoid deficiency leads to increased potassium retention and sodium wasting, resulting in a decreased Na:K ratio. Hyponatremia and hyperkalemia are common laboratory findings.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Primary adrenal insufficiency (Addison's disease) is characterized by decreased protein catabolism (not increased), hypotension, decreased ECF volume, and a decreased sodium to potassium ratio due to deficiency of glucocorticoids and mineralocorticoids.

choices.text: FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 < 30%
FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 <70%
FEV1/FVC<0.7 and FEV1< 50%
Both A and C

questions.text: The Gold's criteria for very severe COPD is: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 < 30%

 

Option A:

 

According to the GOLD (Global Initiative for Chronic Obstructive Lung Disease) criteria for staging chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), very severe COPD is classified as Stage IV. This stage is defined by a FEV1/FVC ratio (forced expiratory volume in one second/forced vital capacity) less than 0.7, which indicates the presence of airflow limitation, and a FEV1 less than 30% of the predicted value. This level of FEV1 signifies a very severe reduction in lung function and typically corresponds with significant symptoms and health status impairment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Note:

 

  • Currently Class C+D have been combined and called Class E
  • Classification of types have been updated.

 

Reference: GOLD 2023 guidelines

questions.text: Which of the following signs and symptoms is not highly specific for iron deficiency? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Macroglossia

 

Explanation:

 

Macroglossia (abnormally enlarged tongue) is not a specific finding in iron deficiency anemia. It occurs instead in conditions like amyloidosis, hypothyroidism, and certain genetic disorders such as Down syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pagophagia (ice eating): This specific form of pica is highly characteristic of iron deficiency. The craving and consumption of ice is a well-recognized manifestation that strongly suggests iron deficiency when present.

 

Option B. Koilonychia ("spoon nails"): These thin, concave nails with raised edges develop gradually in chronic iron deficiency anemia and serve as a helpful diagnostic sign when present.

 

Option C. Blue Sclera: The bluish discoloration of the sclera occurs in advanced iron deficiency due to thinning of collagen, which allows the underlying choroidal veins to become visible. This finding strongly points to significant iron deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pagophagia, koilonychia, and blue sclera are recognized clinical manifestations of iron deficiency anemia, while macroglossia is not part of this clinical picture and suggests alternative diagnoses.

choices.text: Sleep EEG studies have shown disruption in REM sleep
SPECT studies have shown reduced blood flow to the thalamus

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Fibromyalgia is accurate? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sleep EEG studies have shown disruption in REM sleep

 

Fibromyalgia (FM) is characterized by chronic widespread musculoskeletal pain and tenderness with associated neuropsychological symptoms including fatigue, unrefreshing sleep, cognitive dysfunction, anxiety, and depression. Sleep disturbance is one of the key neuropsychological symptoms reported by FM patients. Sleep EEG studies in fibromyalgia patients consistently demonstrate interruption of deep sleep patterns by intrusion of alpha waves, which leads to disruption in REM sleep. This sleep architecture disturbance contributes to the unrefreshing sleep and persistent fatigue reported by patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. More common in males: This is incorrect. Fibromyalgia is far more common in women than in men, with a ratio of ~9:1 in clinical settings. Even in population-based surveys, the female-to-male ratio is 2-3:1. The epidemiological data clearly demonstrates a strong female predominance in this condition.

 

Option C. Increased cortisol response to stress: This is incorrect. Fibromyalgia is not associated with increased cortisol response to stress. In fact, fibromyalgia is often associated with dysregulation of the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis, but this typically manifests as a blunted cortisol response rather than an increased response.

 

Option D. SPECT studies have shown reduced blood flow to the thalamus: This is incorrect. While central nervous system involvement is key in fibromyalgia pathophysiology, there is no established evidence showing SPECT studies with reduced blood flow to the thalamus as a consistent finding in this condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sleep disturbance is a core feature of fibromyalgia, with objective EEG abnormalities showing alpha wave intrusion into deeper sleep stages and REM disruption, contributing to the unrefreshing sleep and persistent fatigue that characterize this condition.

choices.text: May be confused with Zollinger-Ellison Syndrome

questions.text: All of the following statements about Menetrier’s disease are true, except: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Usually increased acid secretion

 

Explanation:

 

Ménétrier's disease is characterized by decreased gastric acid secretion, not increased secretion. The disease features massive foveolar hyperplasia with marked reduction in oxyntic glands and parietal cells, which are responsible for acid production. Histologically, there is hyperplasia of surface and glandular mucous cells with a marked reduction in oxyntic glands, parietal cells, and chief cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is a premalignant condition: Ménétrier's disease is considered premalignant by some clinicians, though the exact risk of neoplastic progression is not well defined.

 

Option C. May be confused with Zollinger: Ellison Syndrome - Both conditions can present with similar symptoms including abdominal pain, though ZES has increased acid secretion while Ménétrier's has decreased acid secretion.

 

Option D. Associated with protein: losing enteropathy - Twenty to 100% of patients with Ménétrier's disease develop a protein-losing gastropathy due to hypersecretion of gastric mucus, accompanied by hypoalbuminemia and edema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 Ménétrier's disease is characterized by hypochlorhydria (decreased acid secretion) due to parietal cell loss, which distinguishes it from hypersecretory conditions like Zollinger-Ellison syndrome despite potential overlap in clinical presentation.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient has hypokalemia, hypertension and metabolic alkalosis. What is the most likely etiology? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Liddle’s Syndrome

 

Liddle's syndrome is a genetic disorder characterized by early-onset hypertension, hypokalemia, and metabolic alkalosis due to a gain-of-function mutation in the epithelial sodium channel (ENaC). This mutation leads to increased sodium reabsorption in the distal nephron, which indirectly causes potassium loss and elevated blood pressure. The syndrome mimics hyperaldosteronism but occurs in the absence of elevated aldosterone levels.

 

 

Hypokalemia + HTN causes:

 

Aldosterone Activation

 

  • Liddle syndrome (ENaC channel Gain of function mutation)
  • Apparent Mineralocorticoid Excess (AME) (11Beta-HSD loss of function)
    • ↓11-βHSD→↑Cortisol →↑Stimulation of MR receptor → HTN + Hypokalemia + alkalosis
  • Geller Syndrome (Mineralocorticoid mutation responding to progesterone): Presents in pregnancy. Rx with specific drug like Finerenone.
  • Glucocorticoid remediable Hyperaldosteronism (GRA): Chimeric gene b/w CYP11B1, B2 causing ACTH driven hyperaldosteronism.
  • Primary Hyperaldosteronism

 

Other options:

 

Option A : Bartter syndrome mimics loop diuretics which occur due to loss of function of Na+-K+-2Cl- transporter at the Loop of Henle. Often patient has NORMOTENSION.

 

Option C : Gitelman syndrome mimics thiazide diuretic occurring due to loss of function mutation of Na+-Cl- transporter in DCT. Both Bartter and Gitelman syndrome are normotensive

 

Option D : Gordon syndrome is opposite of Gitelman syndrome characterized by Gain of function mutation to Na+-Cl- channel which occurs either due to GOF of WNT1 pathway (OR) LOF of WNT 4 pathway, leads to inhibition of ROMK channel causing HYPERKALEMIA.

 

Note: Gordon = HTN + Hyperkalemia

 

Educational Objective:

 

Liddle's syndrome is characterized by hypertension, hypokalemia, and metabolic alkalosis due to increased activity of sodium channels in the distal nephron, not due to increased aldosterone, distinguishing it from other similar electrolyte disorders.

 

Reference - Harrison 21E/ Physiology of Kidney/Chap 309 - Table 309-1

questions.text: A 20-year-old male came to the emergency after sustaining an injury and was given 0.25% bupivacaine for regional anesthesia. A few minutes later, he became unresponsive and pulseless. What would be the ideal management? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. CPR & 20% IV Intralipid

 

The scenario describes a case of local anesthetic systemic toxicity (LAST), which can occur after the administration of local anesthetics like bupivacaine. LAST can cause severe cardiovascular and central nervous system toxicity, leading to symptoms such as seizures, coma, and cardiovascular collapse, as seen in this patient.

 

The management of LAST involves:

 

  1. Immediate initiation of cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) if the patient is unresponsive and pulseless.
  2. Administration of 20% intravenous lipid emulsion (Intralipid). This treatment, known as lipid rescue or lipid emulsion therapy, acts by creating a "lipid sink" that absorbs the local anesthetic from the tissues and blood, reducing its toxic effects on the heart and brain.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CPR & Calcium gluconate: Calcium gluconate is not the primary treatment for local anesthetic toxicity. It is used in cases of hyperkalemia or calcium channel blocker overdose.

 

Option C. CPR & Start Dobutamine infusion: While dobutamine can support cardiac function, it is not specific for treating local anesthetic toxicity and does not address the underlying cause.

 

Option D. CPR & Start NaHCO3 infusion: Sodium bicarbonate is used to treat metabolic acidosis and certain poisonings, such as tricyclic antidepressant overdose, but it is not specific for local anesthetic toxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For local anesthetic systemic toxicity (LAST), immediate management includes starting CPR and administering 20% intravenous lipid emulsion (Intralipid) therapy. This approach helps to rapidly reduce the toxic effects of the local anesthetic on the cardiovascular and central nervous systems.

choices.text: Raised JVP with normal waveform

questions.text: A patient presents to you with an irregularly irregular pulse of 120/minute and a pulse deficit of 20. Which of the following would be the JVP finding? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Absent a wave

 

The patient presents with an irregularly irregular pulse, which is highly suggestive of atrial fibrillation (AF). Atrial fibrillation is characterized by the absence of coordinated atrial contractions, leading to an irregularly irregular ventricular response. This irregularity can be confirmed by a pulse deficit, where the heart rate (as measured by auscultation) is higher than the pulse rate (as felt at the periphery).

 

In atrial fibrillation, the chaotic atrial activity results in the absence of effective atrial contraction. This leads to the absence of a wave in the jugular venous pulse (JVP), as a wave is generated by atrial contraction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Absent p wave: While it is true that atrial fibrillation is characterized by the absence of P waves on the ECG, the question specifically asks about the JVP finding, not the ECG finding.

 

Option C. Cannon a wave: Cannon a waves are typically seen in conditions where there is atrioventricular dissociation, such as complete heart block. They are not associated with atrial fibrillation.

 

Option D. Raised JVP with normal waveform: Raised JVP can occur in various conditions, but the presence of a normal waveform would not be consistent with atrial fibrillation, where the a wave is absent.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In atrial fibrillation, the jugular venous pulse (JVP) typically shows an absent a wave due to the lack of coordinated atrial contraction.

questions.text: A child presents with Hb 6.3 with a history of repeated blood transfusions. Investigations show MCV- 70 fl and the peripheral smear showed a hypochromic microcytic picture. Which of the following investigations should be done next in this child? (FMGE DEC 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hb electrophoresis

 

The clinical picture of hypochromic microcytic anemia and the need for repeated blood transfusions suggest a hemoglobinopathy such as thalassemia. Hemoglobin electrophoresis is the definitive test for diagnosing hemoglobinopathies by identifying abnormal hemoglobin variants.

 

Without the history of blood transfusions, the initial approach would be to conduct serum iron studies to rule out iron deficiency anemia. However, the presence of repeated blood transfusions in this scenario points towards a possible diagnosis of thalassemia, as frequent transfusions can mask iron deficiency and lead to iron overload, making hemoglobin electrophoresis crucial for confirming thalassemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Serum Iron studies: Useful for diagnosing iron deficiency anemia but not for hemoglobinopathies.

 

Option B. Direct Coombs test: Used for diagnosing autoimmune hemolytic anemia, not relevant here.

 

Option C. Osmotic fragility test: Used for diagnosing hereditary spherocytosis, not suggested by the clinical picture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hb electrophoresis is essential for diagnosing hemoglobinopathies like thalassemia in a child with a hypochromic microcytic anemia and history of repeated transfusions.

questions.text: Which of the following type of hypersensitivity reactions is seen in Myasthenia gravis? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Type 2 hypersensitivity reaction

 

Myasthenia gravis is an autoimmune disorder where antibodies (mainly against the acetylcholine receptor) mediate the disease process. This is classified as a type 2 hypersensitivity reaction, where antibodies target cell surface antigens.

 

Important Antibodies in Myasthenia Gravis: Acetylcholine Receptor Antibodies (MC), anti-Musk antibodies and anti-LRP4 Antibodies

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Type 1 hypersensitivity reaction: IgE-mediated allergic reactions like bronchial asthma

 

Option C. Type 3 hypersensitivity reaction: Immune complex-mediated, e.g., systemic lupus erythematosus.

 

Option D. Type 4 hypersensitivity reaction: T-cell mediated, e.g., contact dermatitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Myasthenia gravis is mediated by antibodies and classified as a type 2 hypersensitivity reaction.
